messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

models.py: # This file will contain the data models
views.py: # This file will contain the routes and views
utils.py: # This file will contain utility functions

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python Flask project and set up the necessary files and directories. The main files will include `app.py` for the Flask application, `models.py` for the data models, `views.py` for the routes and views, and `utils.py` for utility functions. Also, create a `requirements.txt` file to list all the necessary Python packages. The packages will include Flask, pytest, and any other necessary packages. After setting up the project structure, write tests to ensure that the project structure is set up correctly and that all necessary files and directories exist.

Step 2: Define the data models in `models.py`. The data models will include `User`, `URL`, and `Click`. The `User` model will have fields for username, password, and a list of URLs. The `URL` model will have fields for the original URL, the shortened URL, the user who created it, the creation date, the expiration date, and a list of clicks. The `Click` model will have fields for the URL, the date/time of the click, and the geographical location of the clicker. After defining the data models, write tests to ensure that the data models are defined correctly and that all necessary fields exist.

Step 3: Implement the URL shortening functionality in `utils.py`. This will include functions to validate a URL, generate a unique shortened URL, and optionally allow users to choose a custom short link. After implementing the URL shortening functionality, write tests to ensure that the URL shortening functionality works correctly. The tests should check that the functions correctly validate URLs, generate unique shortened URLs, and allow users to choose custom short links.

Step 4: Implement the redirection functionality in `views.py`. This will involve creating a route that takes a shortened URL, looks up the corresponding original URL, and redirects to it. After implementing the redirection functionality, write tests to ensure that the redirection functionality works correctly. The tests should check that accessing a shortened URL correctly redirects to the original URL.

Step 5: Implement the analytics functionality in `utils.py`. This will include functions to record a click when a shortened URL is accessed, and retrieve statistics about a shortened URL. The statistics should include the number of clicks, the date/time of each click, and the geographical location of each clicker. After implementing the analytics functionality, write tests to ensure that the analytics functionality works correctly. The tests should check that the functions correctly record clicks and retrieve statistics.

Step 6: Implement the user account functionality in `views.py`. This will involve creating routes to allow users to create accounts, view their shortened URLs, edit their shortened URLs, delete their shortened URLs, and view analytics for their shortened URLs. After implementing the user account functionality, write tests to ensure that the user account functionality works correctly. The tests should check that users can correctly create accounts, view their shortened URLs, edit their shortened URLs, delete their shortened URLs, and view analytics for their shortened URLs.

Step 7: Implement the admin dashboard functionality in `views.py`. This will involve creating routes to allow administrators to view all shortened URLs, delete any URL or user account, and monitor system performance and analytics. After implementing the admin dashboard functionality, write tests to ensure that the admin dashboard functionality works correctly. The tests should check that administrators can correctly view all shortened URLs, delete any URL or user account, and monitor system performance and analytics.

Step 8: Implement the URL expiration functionality in `utils.py`. This will include a function to check whether a shortened URL has expired. After implementing the URL expiration functionality, write tests to ensure that the URL expiration functionality works correctly. The tests should check that the function correctly determines whether a shortened URL has expired.

Step 9: Integrate all the functionalities in `app.py`. This will involve setting up the Flask application, importing the routes from `views.py`, and running the application. After integrating all the functionalities, write tests to ensure that the application runs correctly and that all functionalities are integrated correctly.

Step 10: Finally, run all the tests using pytest to ensure that all functionalities work correctly and that all requirements are met. If any tests fail, debug the code and fix the issues until all tests pass.
step: Step 2: Define the data models in `models.py`. The data models will include `User`, `URL`, and `Click`. The `User` model will have fields for username, password, and a list of URLs. The `URL` model will have fields for the original URL, the shortened URL, the user who created it, the creation date, the expiration date, and a list of clicks. The `Click` model will have fields for the URL, the date/time of the click, and the geographical location of the clicker. After defining the data models, write tests to ensure that the data models are defined correctly and that all necessary fields exist.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
### **Online URL Shortening Service**

**Overview**:
A service that allows users to submit long URLs and then receive a shortened version of that URL for ease of sharing.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

1. **URL Shortening**:
   - [ ] 1.1. Users can input a URL to be shortened.
   - [ ] 1.2. The system validates that the URL is active and legitimate.
   - [ ] 1.3. The system generates a unique shortened URL.
   - [ ] 1.4. Users can choose custom short links (subject to availability).

2. **Redirection**:
   - [ ] 2.1. Accessing the shortened URL redirects to the original URL.

3. **Analytics**:
   - [ ] 3.1. Users can view statistics about their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 3.2. View number of clicks.
   - [ ] 3.3. View date/time of each click.
   - [ ] 3.4. View geographical location of the clicker.

4. **User Accounts**:
   - [ ] 4.1. Users can create accounts.
   - [ ] 4.2. Account holders can view all their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 4.3. Account holders can edit or delete their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 4.4. Account holders can view analytics for all their shortened URLs.

5. **Admin Dashboard**:
   - [ ] 5.1. Administrators can view all shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 5.2. Administrators can delete any URL or user account.
   - [ ] 5.3. Administrators can monitor system performance and analytics.

6. **Expiration**:
   - [ ] 6.1. Users can set an expiration date/time for the shortened URL.
```

Once the code is complete it will be unit tested against the following tests, it ideally should pass all tests:```
import pytest
from random import randint, choices
import string
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

# Helper Functions
def random_url():
    return f"https://example{randint(1000, 9999)}.com"

def random_username():
    return 'user' + ''.join(choices(string.ascii_lowercase + string.digits, k=5))

def random_slug():
    return ''.join(choices(string.ascii_lowercase + string.digits, k=8))

# Test Functions
class TestURLShorteningService:

    def test_input_url_shortening(self):
        url = random_url()
        shortened_url = shorten_url(url)
        assert isinstance(shortened_url, str)
        assert len(shortened_url) < len(url)

    def test_url_validation(self):
        valid_url = random_url()
        invalid_url = "htp:/invalid" + ''.join(choices(string.ascii_lowercase + string.digits, k=10))
        assert validate_url(valid_url) is True
        assert validate_url(invalid_url) is False

    def test_unique_shortened_url(self):
        url = random_url()
        shortened_url1 = shorten_url(url)
        shortened_url2 = shorten_url(url)
        assert shortened_url1 != shortened_url2

    def test_custom_short_link(self):
        url = random_url()
        custom_slug = random_slug()
        custom_short_url = shorten_url(url, custom_slug)
        assert custom_slug in custom_short_url

    def test_redirection(self):
        original_url = random_url()
        shortened_url = shorten_url(original_url)
        redirected_url = redirect(shortened_url)
        assert redirected_url == original_url

    def test_analytics_retrieval(self):
        shortened_url = shorten_url(random_url())
        analytics = get_analytics(shortened_url)
        assert 'clicks' in analytics
        assert 'click_dates' in analytics
        assert 'click_geolocations' in analytics

    def test_user_account_functions(self):
        username = random_username()
        user = create_user(username, "password")
        assert user is not None
        urls = user.get_shortened_urls()
        assert isinstance(urls, list)
        user.edit_url("old_short_url", "new_short_url")
        assert "new_short_url" in user.get_shortened_urls()
        user.delete_url("new_short_url")
        assert "new_short_url" not in user.get_shortened_urls()
        analytics = user.get_analytics("short_url")
        assert analytics is not None

    def test_admin_functions(self):
        admin = create_admin("admin_username", "admin_password")
        all_urls = admin.get_all_urls()
        assert isinstance(all_urls, list)
        admin.delete_url("some_short_url")
        assert "some_short_url" not in admin.get_all_urls()
        admin.delete_user("username")
        assert admin.get_user("username") is None
        system_stats = admin.get_system_stats()
        assert system_stats is not None

    def test_url_expiration(self):
        url = random_url()
        expiration_time = datetime.now() + timedelta(minutes=randint(1, 60))
        shortened_url = shorten_url(url, expiration_time=expiration_time)
        assert check_expiration(shortened_url) is False
        # Additional code to simulate waiting until after expiration may be required

```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
